Posts.Content: I will also preface that I am not a doctor, but will chuck my thoughts into the ring. I'm currently going through a similar though/decision process that you are (or have been). As you can see from my signature, my original biopsy of 3+3 was upgraded to 4+3 with tertiary 5. In my case, the more aggressive (4 with the 5) tumor(s) were near the positive margin area. The RO said that the size and location of the margins relative to tumors meant that in my case, I should consider myself stage 3 for purposes of treatment planning. The question then became whether to move forward with adjuvant radiation in the nearer term, or hold off until BR for salvage radiation, if needed. I still don't know the "right" answer, but I chose adjuvant for a few reasons. First, separately, both my RO and URO recommended it based on current guidance (a link, if it works). http://www.auanet.org/guidelines/rad...uideline-2013) I found similar references in Urology journals and such, too. Secondly, a big part of the recommendation, particularly from the RO, had to do with my age. He suggested that the benefits for me were further down the road, more than ten years in all likelihood. It has to do with when/how recurrence may occur and he likened it to pushing BR down the road 10+ more years. Were I not relatively young, he'd probably recommend waiting on PSA rise/BR. I am currently struggling with the side effect part of it, though. My first PSA is next week and then things start moving more quickly or I have to call a halt. I'm basically fully continent at this point. Certainly nothing that I couldn't live with. Erectile Function still on strike, however. Can't tell if that's permanent or temporary, but I had been hoping for some improvement by now. Fixing at the current level is a little "scary". My docs say that if it never improves there are other things we can do to try and work that problem. Hmmm. Finally, in a mention of the ugly side of things, for me doing adjuvant this year saves me and my family somewhere between $12K and $15K of our money, under our current insurance. Who knows for future depending on where insurance goes -- it's now preexisting. Unfortunately, this is not trivial for us and does enter the decision matrix, although as a secondary concern. I mention this solely in the pursuit of full disclosure about my decision process. Either way, just a point of view supporting the adjuvant idea -- many/most of the folks here seem to prefer or lean toward BR/salvage. There is a logic to both viewpoints. So I'd recommend finding the RO you trust and will rely upon and get information related to your specific situation. Good Luck!
Posts.Signature: Dx 06jan2017, 53yo PSA 7 Gleason 3+3=6, 2 cores from 12, L apex 1mm, 14% and 0.5mm 5% Grade T2a RP Davinci 10 Apr 2017 Final Pathology: 36 grams (4x3x3cm) Tumor 1.8cm greatest dimension, extrapostatic ext. indeterminate Primary Grade 4, Secondary Grade 3, Tertiary Grade 5 (5%) 4mm span positive margin apex "Tumor not obviously beyond the prostate" (at margin), but into striated muscle tissue. Extraprostatic tissues, 5 lymph nodes, seminal vessicles all no malignancy. pT2c, N0, Mx Adjuvant RT scheduled: 39 tx at 70Gy Oct - Dec 2017 PSA: 1/17/2017 (pre surgery)=7 8/17/2017=0.04 10/17/2017=0.06 2/18/2018=0.02 5/22/2018=<.01

Posts.Content: Fixit, I will add my voice to the biopsy folks. I'm 53, and like you, probably didn't even consider the PCa thing at my age. I relied on the advice of my doctor to get the biopsy, mostly cause I needed to know if there was anything to be concerned about. When he first said "biopsy" I envisioned something serious, involved, etc., almost like exploratory surgery. Reality was much different. For me, giving myself an enema turned out to be the worst part of the experience! As others have noted, it was maybe fifteen minutes chatting with the doc while he used some sort of spring-loaded needle gun thing to get samples. Very little discomfort, no pain, and quickly over. Then, several days later I had the information I needed to quiet my imagination. In my case, I then shifted into decision mode, but knowing I had caught mine early, had the maximum number of useful treatment options, with as sure a shot at cure as possible. It's also quite possible that yours is unrelated to PCa at all, which means the biopsy can settle your mind and allow you to move on to other things. Good Luck, I've found the folks here tremendously useful and informative. Dan

As others have noted, it was maybe fifteen minutes chatting with the doc while he used some sort of spring-loaded needle gun thing to get samples. Very little discomfort, no pain, and quickly over. Then, several days later I had the information I needed to quiet my imagination. In my case, I then shifted into decision mode, but knowing I had caught mine early, had the maximum number of useful treatment options, with as sure a shot at cure as possible. It's also quite possible that yours is unrelated to PCa at all, which means the biopsy can settle your mind and allow you to move on to other things. Good Luck, I've found the folks here tremendously useful and informative. Dan

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Next Wednesday I'm meeting the the Radiation Oncologist for the large practice where I've gotten all of my treatment thus far (surgery). I met with this guy before surgery, but since both he and I ended up pointing me down the surgery path, I didn't spend a lot of time worrying about him as a provider for me personally. I've been very pleased with my surgeon and the practice overall (what I've seen of it). Based on my research and discussions with my Dr. Ruff, my uro, it looks likely the way forward will include adjuvant radiation treatments, likely sometime after the first of August (first post-surgical PSA/followup uro visit). Since my current insurance (through wife's work) ends with this month, and new plan is worse, at least for cost (thousands more deductible, less coinsurance, etc.) and likely coverage, I'm going to see the RO before the end of the month for an initial consult on this path. As a review, the adjuvant is suggested because of the upgrade from 3+3 to 4+3 (w/ 5) and positive margins. So, the question. With the help of you guys here, and other research, I got pretty comfortable with the things I wanted to know about the surgeon to get a feel for expertise prior to surgery. I knew his 3-5 a week, 1000+ totals, etc., demonstrated he was well past the learning curve. I had a good list of questions to ask about outcomes and related. Based on the stuff I learned by asking/exploring, I got really comfortable with the surgeon. I feel like the outcome was great. No incontinence to speak of, healing progressing well, etc. I'm kinda starting over with this kind of radiation stuff. I know that there's a team of folks, RO, dosing specialists, etc, that work to design and monitor the treatment and progress. What I don't know is if there are any specific questions or areas of interest I should be pursuing at this consult to help me know if this is the guy/team. I know he did his residency at Loyola and then stayed on as a prof there and ended up director of the residency program for the RO's. His specialties (at least what he publishes about) are Prostate, Bladder, and Breast cancers. That all seems great, but I'd like any advice you guys have on things I should be asking or watching for. As I said, this is really an exploratory/planning consult designed to figure out if adjuvant is the right idea and how/when he'd proceed. Thanks in advance.

Posts.Title: Adjuvant Radiation/Oncologist question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Sorry about the insurance change at the end of May and hope your out of pocket expenses are not crippling. Also, it is unlikely that insurance will cover AR/SR with an undetectable PSA It is possible that you may never experience Biochemical Recurrence (BR). In this scenario, having AR/SR would be a total waste of time, $250K and would create unnecessary radiation damage to healthy tissues. IMO, I would aim to buy as much time as possible prior to starting AR/SR in order to maximally regain functions. Simultaneously, I would fervently hope for the best = BR does not happen! Good luck! MF Thanks, Michael. The costs won't likely be crippling, especially if I can get them covered in the same year with the surgery, just "unfortunate". Insurance not covering is my biggest fear, really. According to my uro doc, the American Urological Assoc. and the Amer. Soc. for Rad. Oncology, plus others, the current recommendation for "best practices" given my pathology is to do adjuvant radiation therapy. Sort of the definition of adjuvant is post-surgery, pre-BR radiation. The PSA is expected/required to be undetectable to do it. If you wait until BR, regardless of timeframe, it is considered salvage radiation. As my doc describes it, adjuvant is a "hit it while it's weakened and down and hasn't had any chances to grow/spread/get stronger" approach. Given the combination of higher risk (4+3 w/5) and positive margins, the probability of BR is much higher than if I'd had clean margins. Another advantage for me is that adjuvant is generally recommended without hormone therapy (leave that bullet in the gun) where this RO already told me pre-surgery that salvage/primary would include months of HT prior to radiation to weaken the cancer. From what I've read and just imagined, hormone therapy sounds like some very undesirable side effects... Adjuvant, from what I understand, must happen within 12 months of surgery, or you default to waiting until recurrence and salvage (I think because you would then need the HT to weaken vs surgical weakening). So, this whole thing will hinge on getting the insurance coverage to do it -- who knows. However, the crux of my question was more to selecting RO. I've seen/read/participated in lots of discussions about how to select the right surgeon. Rates/numbers of procedures, etc. But I haven't seen as much, or just not found it, about how to select a RO to direct radiation therapy. I "get" the idea of a learning curve on surgery in general and davinci in specific. Less clear about such things on a big x-ray machine. So if anyone has thoughts about that side of things, have at it. Thanks for your rapid and, as usual, thoughtful reply. Dan

Posts.Title: Adjuvant Radiation/Oncologist question

Posts.Content: Dave, As everyone has noted, you can relax until Dec. I suspect that the consult will give you a lot of information about the combination of your pathology and other disease characteristics, combined with a post-RALP PSA and how that figures in expected future risk of progression (likely very low in every case). This will simply help you make an educated and reasonable decision about future treatment planning. Remember, there's nothing to worry about until there IS something to worry about -- which it looks like you don't have right now. Adjuvant is an "aggressive" radiation approach that uses radiation before Biochemical Recurrence. I'm doing it based on my own slightly adverse pathology and the PSA results. It was presented to me as "always a choice" -- salvage, done after indications of recurrence is less of one. Good luck and just focus on recovery right now.

Posts.Title: Just got pathology pT3a and appointment with radiation oncologist

Posts.Content: Hey, Bob. I'll go ahead be the outlier. Since you didn't ask whether or not you should get surgery, and suggested you'd been reading the stuff here from all the guys, I'll assume you made a reasoned treatment decision based on sound medical advice, etc. As folks here have repeatedly said, once you make your decision, don't second guess or look back. As a young guy, you've an excellent chance of a quick recovery and good outcome. I know the catheter was a weird idea for me, too. I'd had them post-operatively in the hospital before, but never for a week at a time at home. Although kinda odd and inconvenient in many ways, not having to hop up and traipse to the john all day and night was nice, too. It wasn't as bad, or creepy, as I'd feared -- especially after getting used to the cleaning and lubricating regimen (lubrication helped a LOT). Good Luck on your surgery and recovery. We'll look forward to seeing you in the zero club in a couple months....

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed & Taking the DaVinci Plunge (6/26/2017)

Posts.Content: Although my RO didn't care one way or the other, I had a relatively long overdue colonoscopy about a month prior to the onset of adjuvant radiation. They removed the polyps (I'd had some on an earlier scoping, too) and ensured benign. I think the RO wanted about 3 weeks+ between the colonoscopy and the first treatment. Although I, like RobLee, continue to suffer from the radiation proctitis, though improved, after two months post radiation. I don't think they're related, and neither does the RO. I just wanted to have a baseline and know that my colon was clear before adding the radiation to the mix. Seems a reasonable precaution to me.

Posts.Content: Just to illustrate how crazy this stuff is. The hospital billed my insurance for just over $114,000 for facilities, etc. The insurance paid just over $11,000 (negotiated rates). Doc was about 8k, then there was a bunch of radiology, labs, anesthesiology, etc. They all added about 6-10k more, all said and done. My portion (i'm not old enough for medicare, it's my wife's employer plan) was about 8.5k. That's why I'm pushing to finish radiation this year. If I waited to or go past jan 1, it would cost another 8.5k (that's the annual max after 6.5k deductible). When I asked my RO during my consult, he just said, figure it will cost you whatever your annual maximum is....he was right!

Posts.Title: RALP...Nobody ever discussed costs ! What are they ?

Posts.Content: Djin, as one who is about to start the course of adjuvant this month, I offer the following. From discussions with both my URO and RO, as well as the research I've done myself, I think that if the ONLY adverse pathological finding was a fully contained G9, the "best practices" would suggest a "salvage radiation approach". That is, monitor PSA and only intervene if the PSA rises above the BR threshold. In my case, it was the combination of significant positive margins and much upgraded grading in the pathology, including G5 cells near the margin, that changed things. According to the RO, for treatment planning purposes, the pathology and other attributes of my disease meant treating me as Stage 3, although the final official grading was T2C. Thus, I will get Adjuvant. My own research turned up at least one of the studies your original quotes referenced. That is, with someone having the pathological attributes I do, there are proven advantages to adjuvant radiation. The advantages are not so much proven with regards to mortality, but rather in the time to a potential recurrence. I don't remember the actual numbers in the studies I read, but they were something like pushing recurrence out from 5 years to ten+ years. If recurrence happens at all, of course. For me, given my relatively young age, the difference between potentially facing the next steps of HT, Chemo, etc., beginning at maybe 64 versus 58 has definite appeal. We always have to make these treatment decisions in probability space, which is kinda hard. The cost, SE, etc., happen now and with relative certainty. The benefits happen in future maybe-land. My RO has been involved with some of the research in these areas, and agrees with the idea that given the parameters summarized in RobLee's post above, there are sufficient benefits to a more aggressive adjuvant approach to warrant the cost and SE's (I do note, however, that he's not suffering the SE's). He told me that if all I had was a more aggressive gleason scoring, I'd be on the wait and see approach. The other thing I'd emphasize, too, is the considerations regarding age. Both my URO and RO have repeatedly pointed out that as a 53yo (turned 54 couple weeks ago, after all decision making), 5 yr, 10 yr, 15 yr, etc, projections and prognoses have a different meaning than for the average 68 or 69 year old patient. This is true both because of the obvious "how old will you be when it happens" connections as well as differences in the behavior and understanding of the behavior of the disease in younger men... At least, that's what I've been told. Hopefully this is not just rambling and provides useful info.

Posts.Title: Criteria for RT after RP: Adjuvant vs. Salvage

Posts.Content: Djin, as one who is about to start the course of adjuvant this month, I offer the following. From discussions with both my URO and RO, as well as the research I've done myself, I think that if the ONLY adverse pathological finding was a fully contained G9, the "best practices" would suggest a "salvage radiation approach". That is, monitor PSA and only intervene if the PSA rises above the BR threshold. In my case, it was the combination of significant positive margins and much upgraded grading in the pathology, including G5 cells near the margin, that changed things. According to the RO, for treatment planning purposes, the pathology and other attributes of my disease meant treating me as Stage 3, although the final official grading was T2C. Thus, I will get Adjuvant. My own research turned up at least one of the studies your original quotes referenced. That is, with someone having the pathological attributes I do, there are proven advantages to adjuvant radiation. The advantages are not so much proven with regards to mortality, but rather in the time to a potential recurrence. I don't remember the actual numbers in the studies I read, but they were something like pushing recurrence out from 5 years to ten+ years. If recurrence happens at all, of course. For me, given my relatively young age, the difference between potentially facing the next steps of HT, Chemo, etc., beginning at maybe 64 versus 58 has definite appeal. We always have to make these treatment decisions in probability space, which is kinda hard. The cost, SE, etc., happen now and with relative certainty. The benefits happen in future maybe-land. My RO has been involved with some of the research in these areas, and agrees with the idea that given the parameters summarized in RobLee's post above, there are sufficient benefits to a more aggressive adjuvant approach to warrant the cost and SE's (I do note, however, that he's not suffering the SE's). Both my URO and RO have repeatedly pointed out that as a 53yo (turned 54 couple weeks ago, after all decision making), 5 yr, 10 yr, 15 yr, etc, projections and prognoses have a different meaning than for the average 68 or 69 year old patient. This is true both because of the obvious "how old will you be when it happens" connections as well as differences in the behavior and understanding of the behavior of the disease in younger men... At least, that's what I've been told. Hopefully this is not just rambling and provides useful info.

Posts.Title: Criteria for RT after RP: Adjuvant vs. Salvage

Posts.Content: Hi, Cproman, I'm probably similar to your case in many ways. I was diagnosed at 53, had surgery, then found more advanced disease on post-op pathology. Based on my positive margin, also no lymph involvment nor seminal vessicles, I was aimed at ART. My post operative PSAs were very low (see signature) but showed slight increases. I underwent IMRT last fall. I didn't consider proton, but wouldn't have had insurance coverage for it in any case. In discussions with my RO, the explanation for choice of methodology involved the nature of the target and such. The presumption was that there were limited numbers of cells left in the prostate bed in the neighborhood of the margin. The low PSA numbers and lack of any indication of vessicle/node invasion, nor any widespread extraprostatic extension, suggested a small, still somewhat localized community of cancer cells. This is sort of right in the sweet spot of how IMRT would have maximum effectiveness. With a larger, denser mass of tissue (like a prostate gland), more things would be in play as possibilities. I admit that my guy's expertise and experience was primarily in IMRT, so that may have tilted the field a bit, but he was definitely able to address SBRT and believed that in my kind of case, and where they'd be targeting (alongside colon/bladder), the spread out treatments resulted in fewer negative side effects. Like everyone, I only had the one treatment modality so cannot compare to others personally. However, my side effects were not really bad in the big picture. I had a persistent case of radiation proctitis that set in about 2/3 of the way through the treatments. It lasted nearly six months after. About a week ago it magically resolved itself, though I've now had a bit of slight stress incontinence recur. I'm kinda back where I was about a year ago, two months after surgery, on the incontinence track (fully continent, but occasional shield and thought required when lifting/laughing, etc). I now feel better than I have in forever! The good news is that my PSA appears to be effectively zero for the first time since diagnosis. I've gotten my results off the portal but won't see RO for interpretation until Wednesday, but it's the first <.01 I've ever seen on any test I've taken. So, until told otherwise, I'm considering ART completely successful and me disease free!!! So, from my perspective, you're getting solid advice and can easily look forward to a full cure. Good Luck and let me know if you have any questions I can answer or any other information that would help.

Posts.Title: Adjuvant therapy prostatectomy  proton beam vs IMRT?

Posts.Content: I'll second the comments of Another. I don't think you necessarily have a more pessimistic outlook because of your age, but I do think it is something to be aware of. I think this puts a premium on making sure you have a physician you trust and who seems to be experienced with men with your attributes. One of the reasons I went with the guy I did for surgery was that he was able to describe a lot of surgical patients he'd had that were younger, like me. (his youngest was 41). I felt that it made him sensitive to the nuances of the disease in younger men. In fact, he spent a lot of time telling me exactly how his recommendations to me, expectations for the surgery, and other things were modified by my age and WHY (relative to what he'd otherwise suggest/expect in his older patients). While my final pathology was not what I'd hoped for, I remain convinced I made the right choices, for me, and that I had the right guy doing the surgery. Your low PSA (relatively), consistent gleason grading across a number of cores, etc., could also be a reason for optimism. Keep learning and focus on finding the right medical/treatment team for you (you might already have it). Then you can make choices in which you can have comfort and confidence. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: don't know what to believe

Posts.Content: As Michael notes, the margin is a topic for discussion with your URO/RO. In my case, the RO said anything 2mm or less could be effectively ignored as insignificant. May depend on details and such that your URO/RO can help explain, but generally margins 2mm and less are sort of "noise" in the damage to the organ during removal and can be treated differently than larger ones. Lots of folks have posted reliable info supporting the "not all positive margins are meaningful" idea. Good Luck!!!

Posts.Title: Am i at the right path?

Posts.Content: I've just started fourth week (I think today was 15th Tx, with the machine down one day last week). Burning started about the end of the second week, then would abate by early following week and return by end of the week.... Right now, I'm at diarrhea (started today), lots of gas (couple weeks now) with a lot of increased frequency. Not to every 15minutes, yet. Hope that doesn't happen. Doc says it's just the inflammation caused by the treatments and is normal. If it gets a lot worse or changes, then meds or modification of the radiation field will occur. So far it's just uncomfortable and inconvenient. Feels almost exactly like having a UTI, which is what they warned me about. Doc gave me exhaustive list of food/beverage suggestions to mitigate. So far I haven't changed my diet or habits, but that my change soon.... Good Luck!

Posts.Title: post op pathology report

Posts.Content: Well, I had my surgery last Monday. Had to spend an extra night inpatient because BP dropped to about 70/50 and freaked out hospital folks. After CT Scan, lots of blood work, and I don't know how many bags of fluids/antibiotics (I think they gave me every kind they had in stock!)...oh well, looks fine, go home. Just came back from the catheter removal and pathology visit. I'm feeling pretty validated on jumping to surgery quickly, for me. Final pathology was upgraded from 3+3=6 to 4+3=7, with some 5 aggressive stuff in there. The tumor was sneaking along the urethra and being aggressive there, apparently. 4mm wide positive margin at the apex, with striated tissue in sample (meaning my doc got all of the prostate and just into the sphincter muscles). The positive margin was at the sphincter. Vesicles and lymph nodes negative for cancer. Tumor was centrally located and growing toward the apex. Probably some adjuvant radiation in my future, doc says, after/depending on continence. While I've only been in the diaper for a couple of hours, I'm encouraged by the lack of a constant dripping feeling and the feeling that I've cut it off a couple of times. Doc said both nerve bundles looked good and were spared. There was no incursion in that direction and all margins there were solidly negative. He indicated that the conditions inside, smoothness of the surgery, how soon my urine cleared inpatient (they were pushing fluids constantly for two days for the BP scare), and looking at the CT Scan (which they normally don't have 12 hrs. post-op), he thinks I'm a good candidate for a return to continence on the shorter end of the time spectrum. So, overall, pleased with the results. Little worry with the margin/extension, but that's for another month. Just feeling thankful that I moved quickly to surgery. Doc said with the grade 5 hidden in there, waiting would have been, in retrospect, not as positive an approach. Said the tumor was much more advanced and aggressive looking than the pre-surgical numbers/biopsy would have suggested. Might have taken multiple biopsies to catch the aggressive stuff due in part to the long, skinny shape it had. We all like to have our decisions validated, so I'm taking that as a big positive for me. Thanks for all of the support and advice so far. The journey isn't over, but that's the first big bump past. I'll take time to update the signature with the final pathology details later, btw. Next Stop, Continence and Zero Club Membership Application! Dan

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Welcome to the other side, glad you got through the blood pressure thing. That's scary low. There's a big debate ongoing on another forum, about overtreatment. I'm on the other side of it. I might have to use you as an example of a reason to be careful not to UNDERtreat. Glad you got it when you did. Feel free to use as needed. As I'm not a physician or in the medical field (except as patient), I never want to tell folks what to do. It's got to be what one is comfortable with and fits one's individual situation, including financial (which, pre-medicare, mattered a lot to me). But at 53, I was not comfortable with a strategy that rested on deferring surgery just to avoid some side effects (which admittedly don't sound that fun). I guess it's partly how you deal with probability. If the doc said, "you choose, diapers forever or dead" I'd quickly select diapers. Rephrasing to "diapers for a while, maybe forever vs maybe advanced cancer treatments/dead" didn't move the needle a lot for me. Seemed like removal would likely happen sometime, so get the sucker out now, look at what we really have (since biopsy, even guided, only samples a vanishingly small part of the organ), and start that recovery. Right now, I'm lucky enough not to have any other serious health concerns, etc. I'm not convinced I'll always be that way. This is, of course, a lot easier to say glibly since I'm feeling "vindicated" or "lucky" or whatever for choosing correctly that I was in the 28-30% "actual worse than biopsy" group rather than the 70% "see, you could have safely waited 15 years" group. Had I had better pathology results, I'd still be glad I did RP, but probably without the "HA, see!" component of self-congratulation.

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: I think you've got the right priorities, and it seems you've thought through them carefully, which is important. It sounds like you've got a very manageable disease and surgery is a very good option. I also elected surgery, though I was only a 3+3 before surgery, I was 4+3 after. In my case, both nerves spared and recovery going well -- never really incontinent after catheter out (feeling lucky). Although some may disagree, if you have a surgeon in whom you and your Uro have confidence, there's no reason you can't have success outside of a major cancer center. I considered the same option (I'm about three hours from MDAnderson), but since I didn't feel my case was particularly complex or risky the option of the more comfortable home setting and such had advantages. Also for me, the costs and inconvenience of the travel/hotels were a downside. Most importantly, I felt I had a really good surgeon located within my local Urology practice (a pretty big one). He'd done over a thousand and routinely does 3+ per week here. He was/is also (purely coincidentally - kinda blind luck on initial referral) my Uro, so my relationship with him was probably a little different having been through the whole initial visit, biopsy, treatment cycle together. I am firmly of the opinion that my surgical outcomes would not have been very different or better at MDA than here in Austin. By all means, get a second opinion if it makes you feel more comfortable, but I wouldn't be scared off of local surgeon solely because he isn't part of a team at a teaching hospital/cancer center if he has good experience and success treating folks like you. Ask lots of questions and get info from your uro or other docs/nurses you trust. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Mike, I, like Rob, recently finished my ART based on adverse pathology (in my case 4mm positive margin, but no SV/Node involvement). As others have suggested, you are back in probability space. There are a bunch of studies (some in the Djin subforums) that demonstrate long-term benefits (in the form of both survival and avoidance of BCR) to ART in cases of adverse post-surgical pathology. But, likewise, there is no guarantee that you would have the negative outcomes without it. Unfortunately, you can't wait until something bad happens and say, "wait, I want a do-over and do radiation back then", nor can you get radiation and avoid BCR and say "gee, glad I had that radiation that prevented BCR". It kinda comes down to which risk you wanna take. Right now, there are no indications of remaining cancer (<.01 PSA), but the point of ART is to attack potential residual, weakened cancer cells in a sort of preventative manner. My RO was able to articulate the studies and pro/cons. You should be able to get similar input from any good RO. I can't speak directly to proton, but the guidance I received was there was no demonstrable benefit, especially in my ART situation. I didn't have any long-term or horrible side effects from my IMRT -- in fact the minor bowel symptoms (radiation proctitis) have resolved and I now feel back to normal in all ways. I had a slight step backward in continence (I now have a small bit of stress leakage, but only drop or two easily handled by a lightweight shield). I expect that will resolve in time. ED hasn't worsened, nor has it improved since ART. FWIW, I was told the advantages of ART were only present during the first year after surgery. If you didn't get ART by then, it offered no real advantages over wait and do Salvage after PSA rise.

Posts.Title: Catheter is out!

Posts.Content: Sounds like you have a good plan. I think the second opinion approach is good. You need to be completely comfortable with the doc that is doing your care/treatment. I'm in texas (austin) and I feel like I've gotten solid care and had a really good surgery here, without going to MD Andersen. This is nothing against MDA, I can't speak from direct experience. However, it would have raised my costs a lot and it was really nice having a ten minute trip to/from doctor and hospital during all of this. Recovery at home was also comforting. My guy is part of a large practice, (20 docs, 14 offices) that includes all of the RO, URO, Pathology and other stuff under one umbrella. So I feel I got some similar benefits as a cancer center, too. Just make sure you spend a lot of time with both you and your wife asking a lot of questions and getting totally comfortable with both the people and the proposed treatment. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Decision time approaching

Posts.Content: MM is providing his usual good suggestions. I, too, had positive margins with gleason 5 near the margins (graded 4+3, though). I'm currently scheduled for my first PSA next week, which a bit more than 90 days after surgery. I think the suggestion to go ahead and identify and meet with the RO is a good one. The URO/surgeon will likely continue to have some involvement, but for the next phase I think the RO will be your medical practitioner. I met with the RO shortly after I got my surgical pathology results, with the blessing and recommendation of the URO. He (RO) and I walked through options, side effects, timing, etc. I scheduled/reserved my block of radiation times a couple months ago. The plan for me is that if the PSA next week is undetectable, then I do "adjuvant" with no hormone therapy. If the PSA is detectable, then we stop and reassess, likely just moving to "salvage" with HT included. Meanwhile, I've just been doing my exercises, going to physical therapy, and healing up in preparation for the next step. I'm not sure exactly how to select between RO guys, but I wanted someone who does a lot of Prostate cancer treatments. The guy I selected treats primarily prostate cancers. He is practiced at both primary and adjuvant/salvage applications and is active doing research/academic work, as well. He seems very knowledgeable about current practices, and specifically issues/practices in prostate cancer treatment. It seems like meeting with potential RO's to identify the one you will use and getting information about and from him is the best option. The timing you suggested of a PSA in October with treatments after that, as indicated, makes perfect sense to me. I agree with MM that I don't know what information a PSA today really provides (I'm also NOT a doctor). My doc said there was no advantage to doing one earlier and that it just muddied the waters and worried folks with numbers that hadn't "bottomed out" naturally. Good luck moving forward. As others have said, cure is still very much the goal for you.

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Hey, Rob, I don't have the colitis, but I do have a significant, ongoing radiation proctitis thing happening. My RO was taking imaging just prior to each of my 39 tx and said the bladder/rectum were within treatment limits all but about two widely spaced days. FWIW. I don't have the diarrhea, but got all of the urgency. Also, regularity is still not normal. From all of the inflamation, I'll get a lot of discomfort and a feeling of great urgency to defecate, with a very full feeling like I'm harboring bowling balls. Then, instant relief after passing something that resembles (size) a stubby, 2 inch pencil (the thick ones we all used to write on our big chief tablets). I mean, REALLY? Then within an hour or two, recurrence. Then nothing for a day (but the discomfort) and 6 significant events one after another. Again, REALLY? I'm attributing it to having been (in a prior life -- many years ago) a redhead. Sensitive tissues! I've been prescribed hydrocortisone retention enemas (fun--not so much), which do knock it out/back. But I've heard/read a lot of bad things from ongoing use of them. Including during the treatment regimen, I've had six weeks worth of those. I spaced them out a bit (to make them last) so as not to overdo it. My surgeon says they can thin the rectum and cause other problems... I keep hearing it will improve, but it is only doing so in small fits and starts, with backsliding, and is NOT comfortable. This has been the only real impact to daily life except the immediate week or so after surgery. Gas causes rather significant pain/discomfort, and I can't seem to control both sides independently when this happens. I've been continent since just after surgery and gave away my supply of diapers with the idea of staying so. I REFUSE to wear diapers just to try farting safely. So I spend a LOT of quality time in all of the bathrooms in the neighborhood (home and every store, etc., I visit). I'm out of the enemas, so I've got to solo until my RO visit end of May. All of my docs say, "everyone is different" and "just give it time" and "should be getting better soon" and "six months or so" etc. I'm hoping they are right, but you are not alone in this. Good Luck! Hope yours subsides soon.

Posts.Title: More 'good' news, Radiation Colitis

Posts.Content: ASA, My issue with the quoted information is one of presentation. If a person is low risk, and there is no "reason" to do surgery (or radiation, or whatever), then AS makes perfect sense. I just think encouraging decision making pro/con active treatment on the basis of supposed side effect mitigation is not a good approach. If one needs treatment, one should get the treatment that provides the best cure opportunity and minimizes adverse side effects. If one doesn't need treatment, getting treated now in preference to a potential future side effect seems ill advised, generally. I mean, if one defers treatment based on sound medical practice, I think we can agree that ED is not impacted (unless otherwise present in any case). Perhaps we are merely talking about the definition of risk, but I'd hate to think men are getting surgery to "preserve" some concept of erectile function. My understanding is surgery ALWAYS results in ED for some period of time. In my case, the argument for surgery as a young man was never presented to me, nor evaluated, as providing "better ED recovery". It was mentioned that a younger body tolerates surgery better than an older one, generally, but that was all. It was all about likelihood of progression and future disease outcomes. Side effects were discussed separately and no distinction was ever made for them based on age (other than to note that most men eventually suffer reduced erectile function based solely on age). There are probably folks out there being presented information that frames the decision in the manner suggested by the article. But THAT is kinda what disturbs me.

Posts.Title: Thank you and what I learned

Posts.Content: MM is providing his usual good suggestions. I, too, had positive margins with gleason 5 near the margins (graded 4+3, though). I'm currently scheduled for my first PSA next week, which a bit more than 90 days after surgery. I think the suggestion to go ahead and identify and meet with the RO is a good one. The URO/surgeon will likely continue to have some involvement, but for the next phase I think the RO will be your medical practitioner. I met with the RO shortly after I got my surgical pathology results, with the blessing and recommendation of the URO. He (RO) and I walked through options, side effects, timing, etc. I scheduled/reserved my block of radiation times a couple months ago. The plan for me is that if the PSA next week is undetectable, then I do "adjuvant" with no hormone therapy. If the PSA is detectable, then we stop and reassess, likely just moving to "salvage" with HT included. Meanwhile, I've just been doing my exercises, going to physical therapy, and healing up in preparation for the next step. I'm not sure exactly how to select between RO guys, but I wanted someone who does a lot of Prostate cancer treatments. The guy I selected treats primarily prostate cancers. He is practiced at both primary and adjuvant/salvage applications and is active doing research/academic work, as well. He seems very knowledgeable about current practices, and specifically issues/practices in prostate cancer treatment. It seems like meeting with potential RO's to identify the one you will use and getting information about and from him is the best option. The timing you suggested of a PSA in October with treatments after that, as indicated, makes perfect sense to me. I agree with MM that I don't know what information a PSA today really provides (I'm also NOT a doctor). My doc said there was no advantage to doing one earlier and that it just muddied the waters and worried folks with numbers that hadn't "bottomed out" naturally. Good luck moving forward. As others have said, cure is still very much the goal for you.

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: I'm glad I read the article -- as the title of the thread was misleading to me. I chose my treatment modality and timing based solely on the expected efficacy in curing cancer/preventing significant reductions in quality of life from the cancer. Side effects were considered, but only from the standpoint of selecting between alternatives with the same expected efficacy. I personally would be horrified if people were choosing a surgical procedure they didn't need for effective treatment of their cancer only in order to control perceived side effects. I did and do believe that quicker and easier recovery from surgery would apply to me at 53 than 73, but that was also true for other surgeries I've had -- and climbing mountains, etc. Erectile recovery is a part of surgical recovery, but I suspect it is more related to the details of the surgery (amount cut, location of nerves, surgeon experience, etc) than purely age....

Posts.Title: My Follow Up with surgeon 20 months post op

Posts.Content: Dave, I only have one data point -- my RO and my experience -- but I was offered HT, but it was not recommended. To be clear, he was not recommending that I do HT, but was willing to put me on that path if I wanted it. I did not do it. My guy indicated that if I waited for a more definitive BCR, or for a much longer post-surgical waiting period, then he'd recommend it. Had I elected RT as a primary treatment (which he did NOT recommend -- he recommended surgery) he would only do it with HT. From my read of your situation, you are not very much different from my adjuvant course (which my guy said was RT within approximately 12 months), with similar PSA numbers and progression as I had, just maybe six months behind me. I had surgery in April 2017, by the way. If you are interested in exploring avoiding HT right now, I'd consider a second RO opinion. Given that you are potentially acting quickly, it might not prove necessary. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Hey, Jake, sorry to meet you this way, but glad you found us! I'm 54yo (53 at dx), and you will probably hear a lot about age in the recommendations/decision. I know that both my surgeon and my radiation guy suggested surgery based on my age/biopsy. The RO said he'd certainly do the radiation if that was my choice, but went over a number of reasons why he felt it would not offer the best probable cancer cure/quality of life mix. There are advocates for both approaches here, each with passion and thought and consideration in his advocacy. There truly is no one right answer. As to the cancer center thing, I guess I swim a bit against the stream. I live a couple hours from MDA in Houston, so could have done that. For me, having found a surgeon/hospital/RO near me that seemed to me to be qualified and that I liked was very helpful. I understand how the major center process works, and it is different in many ways from the local practice. Some feel it's better, I just think it's different. I don't think all good docs and all good processes exist only at the big centers. I believe that the comfort and familiarity of being at home for recovery and 15 minutes from my docs if there were problems and for followups, etc., really helped me. I know I didn't miss the significant financial strain of staying in a hotel for a week or more, plus travelling, plus not having my family right there... If your case is in some way unusual, by all means head to the cutting edge experts. Otherwise, be open to a good local choice. My guy had done over a thousand and was doing 3-5 per week right here -- and did all of them himself one theater at a time... In any case, I feel like the outcome and process I'm experiencing validated my choice -- or at least didn't invalidate it...

Posts.Title: new member, first post, got the PC news yesterday

Posts.Content: Hey Puzzled, I'll differ a bit, potentially. I think you could definitely seek a bit more information. Either more detailed info or another RO opinion. I also had a 4mm positive gleason 4 (and maybe 5) margin at the base with no other negative findings (other than being bumped from 3+3 to 4+3 with 5% 5). I'm currently through tx 18 of 39 IMRT adjuvant radiation treatments. My medical team recommended this without reference to my post surgical PSA's (unless it had come back really bad, in which case HT would have been part of the plan). I think the key words that might help you refine your understanding and inform your research are "adjuvant radiation" and "salvage radiation". You are not much older than I am (I'm 54). There is industry guidance based on reputable studies that suggest a proactive radiation approach in cases with the margins/pathology you've described. As I'm sure others will point out, no two cases are the same and waiting and monitoring are valid responses. In my case, both the surgeon and RO, separately, explained that although my pathology was a final grade of T2C, for treatment planning purposes prospectively, I'm considered Stage 3. This is because (as explained to me) the 4mm margin is considered "significant" and should therefore be treated as if it were extraprostatic disease. As my surgeon said, it is certainly possible that the last cancer cells were actually destroyed in the cauterized tissues, it is not the only or even most likely result. So act as if there's still stuff there... There are threads and research and other stuff that explores the differences and reasons to pursue adjuvant vs salvage. Adjuvant is the more "proactive" or "aggressive" approach. It is using radiation before there is distinctive evidence of Biochemical Recurrence (elevated PSA). Theory explained to me is sort of hit the remaining cancer cells while they are weakened and shocked by the surgery and removal of the gland. In my case, this eliminates the need for HT, too. Salvage, on the other hand, is the more commonly discussed wait and watch and then jump into radiation as soon as there is an elevated PSA to show recurrence. FYI, generally, adjuvant has to occur within one year of surgery. If you wait a year or longer, it's generally suggested to just wait/monitor until BR occurs. Theory being that if everything is fully recovered at a year, the cells are no longer shocked/weakened. This is as it was explained to me by my medical folks and research... In any case, sounds like your team is suggesting adjuvant radiation. Do some research and ask some questions. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: So far so good with radiation

Posts.Content: Well, I know you don't really want to hear "be patient, it takes time" again, but it's probably the answer. I had my surgery April 10th. I achieved continence 95%+ immediately after catheter removed. Doc said both nerves spared. Stopped thinking of continence by about the end of July or so (never a drip and didn't feel like it was a threat). Started seeing beginnings of movement below decks at about the first of August, so deferred adjuvant radiation to see what would happen (as late as I could to end of Oct). By the end of October, lets call it half staff or so (with optimism, maybe). Working with the pump gives some functionality. Radiation stopped my progress, but for reference, I was hitting or beating all of the milestones my surgeon laid out, from continence to ED. He said that after about a year, I'd be at a reasonable approximation of permanent function, with the end state represented by the 24month mark. I've not tried injections or anything, but there are options I keep being told. All of that to say that I think it's way too early to make any judgments for the long term. Although I agree with and understand your current frustration, I don't think it's probably helping the situation. Stress can even cause ED without PCa. With the other positive things you've said about your surgery and recovery, I'd look forward to a happier spring! Hang in there!

Posts.Title: ED.....Patience??....Feeling a tad useless down there

Posts.Content: AS, I suspect you are right on the timeframe reasoning. I was having an interesting discussion with a guy I met at a gaming group I'm part of. He has a lot of family history of PCa (Father, at least one brother, and grandfather). He'd been reading about the problems of over-treatment and not getting a PSA test (I think from a "TV doctor" or something). I think he wanted to feel there was nothing to worry about. He was also asking about alternative/nutritional approaches, for which I was a poor advocate. It led to a bit of interesting dialog about the difference between medical system decision making and individual decision making. I certainly fit within the parameters of someone who has been "overtreated" based on all indicators prior to surgery. But I can verify I feel closer to undertreated (like why wasn't this identified sooner, which it probably would have if I'd been getting PSA tests from the time BPH was identified several years ago) than overtreated. My GP was going with the "no routine PSA" guidance to avoid overtreatment. So nothing happened until the DRE indicated something was already there. I can't fault him in that he was just following the medical community guidance -- which often does seem to overtest, etc. But I still wish I'd had an opportunity to decide and intervene a few years ago... It makes PCa a difficult problem.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all of the advice. I haven't asked for second evaluation for the pathology because I'm not sure it would be money well spent for me. Unless it's likely to change it to "no cancer" (seems unlikely given three doctors noting DRE physical indications), or bump up to gleason 8 or 9, then I don't think it would significantly modify my approach. In the first instance, of course I wouldn't have any surgery if there were no carcinoma. In the second, unless it was changed to be significantly advanced (stage three or better) and aggressive, I think I'd still opt for surgery. If the pathology had originally come back 4+3 or something, it would make more sense to double check before moving forward too quickly or deciding on imaging tests. Anyway, that's why I've avoided the second opinion path right now. Also, since my pathologist does a lot of cancer (22 urologists in practice) and did the John's Hopkins fellowship, I'm hoping he's pretty good . If I ultimately decide on surveillance, there will be additional biopsy material in my future, too. Anyway, I'll update after seeing doc tomorrow. Thanks again for all of the helpful comments/advice. It's nice just having a bunch of "folks who understand" around.... Dan

Posts.Title: Choosing surgeon

Posts.Content: I'm meeting with my urologist and potential surgeon (he does robotic) Monday Feb 13th. Since I kinda fell backward into this I'm looking for suggestions on choosing surgeon or specific things to watch for/ask. The story: I'm 53 and went in for my annual-ish physical in October. My GP doc found a hard spot on the left apex of my prostate during the DRE. I'd never had a PSA, and didn't really know much about it. He referred me to a nearby urology practice to "have someone verify it/check it out". He never mentioned cancer and I didn't really wonder or worry. The referral was for a practice and he did not offer any preference for a specific physician (I asked). It's a large practice with offices all over the city (Austin, TX). So I picked the closest office, went to my insurance carrier site and health grades and stuff and picked the guy I liked from that sort of casual review. First visit was in mid December. Recommended and did biopsy on 27th. Also did PSA draw. Got the results on Jan 6th. Two cores from twelve positive adenocarcinoma, 5 and 15 percent. Both 3+3=6. PSA came back at 7, for what it's worth. He notes same areas of hardness on DRE. I think from reading Walsh book, talking to this urologist at biopsy results visit, and after seeing the radiation oncologist for the practice, the surgery is the option I'll pursue. I meet the urologist Monday to get results of additional genetic testing on biopsy samples and to discuss next steps. My question, which I'd value the forums input on, is how to determine, if possible, if this is the right guy. I like his manner and what information I've gotten from him has been solid. He's been practicing about 20 years or so, but I won't know until Monday how many he's done. Are there questions beyond number of procedures he's done, or number per year that I should ask? I know MDA in Houston is "close", but that would take longer to set up and cost a lot more for travel and lodging and stuff. From what I can tell, I've been caught early and one would expect a relatively straightforward surgery based on pathology and such, so MDA might not be so "necessary" Anyway, any advice welcome.

Posts.Title: Choosing surgeon

Posts.Content: We did discuss the surveillance thing, but we're leaning toward surgery (wife strongly highly for it). The factors nudging me that way are age and to a lesser degree cancer stage (t2b). According to my doc and the books, etc, the survival rates are fifteen years based on the studies currently out there. That gets me to 68. I told my wife I'd outlive her just to spite her. Unfortunately, women in her family live long, late eighties at least. The doc points out, I think correctly, that toleration of surgery is much better at my current age than ten years older. I'm also thinking I'll never have a better shot at negative margins and spared nerves than than early stage disease. A "cure" has appeal. Your threshold of 300 is good info. I'm also wondering about frequency versus count. It's there any sense of number per week/month to "stay sharp". Taking care of it locally has a lot of appeal since I don't seem to have indications of complex/rare/aggressive disease pushing for cancer center and associated costs. Also, does anyone here have suggestions as to how to get at outcomes when talking to doc? Thanks for the help. Been reading on here for few weeks and the attitude seems very helpful and knowledgeable. Dan

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine - Study Finds No Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hey, Mike, sounds like you're a potential candidate for adjuvant radiation, which I finished first of the year. Generally, from what my Uro and RO told me, IF they are gonna recommend/do adjuvant radiation, they usually wait about six months to schedule it in. Usually target doing it in the last half the year after surgery. This is to allow the body maximum time to heal, gaining 100% continence and as much erectile function as possible before beginning. Usually, the radiation will "freeze" in place the state you have when you begin it (or at least they will tell you that. Since adjuvant is recommended based on clinical/pathological features rather than PSA, additional PSA readings or rises are not really a factor. In my case, I was recommended and planned the radiation without regard to PSA -- they just did one right before the radiation (at six months) to have a baseline. So I wouldn't worry too much about that unless you are considering waiting until a confirmed BCR before proceeding with radiation. In that case, the routine PSA screenings and such are very relevant. Sounds to me like June would be a "normal time" to check in on continence and related side effects and assess for adjuvant. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Recovering now from my surgery

Posts.Content: Tony, I just went through most of what you're facing. My RO recommendations were essentially the same as yours. When I started (A)RT, six months after surgery, I was fully continent. Had been since catheter out, though was more "secure" six months out than earlier. ED was beginning to improve, but not fully resolved. I chose not to do ADT at this time, with RO concurrence as you've suggested yours said, too. The RT was relatively uneventful, with some bothersome radiation proctitis near the end and persisting for a couple months after. That has fully resolved now. My continence slipped a bit, so I went back to a shield and briefs, but nothing serious (slight stress incontinence leakage, but nothing requiring more than just a shield). I'm now back in boxers and out of the shields again. I think carefully before lifting and other kinds of stress, but no leakage anymore. ED has begun to improve a bit more again, so I'm hopeful that will continue to improve over time. I'm at about 50% without assistance, which is the low end of functionality, better with a pump. I'm just a couple of years younger, so hopefully experiences will be similar. Sounds like you've got a really good shot at a "cleanup" and cure. After RT, my PSA is below the threshold of detection = zero! Good Luck.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Hello Guys, it’s been a while. To those of you who have been here a while, it’s good (sort of) to be back, although not for the reasons I’m here. So it looks like I may very well be headed for radiation treatments. And it’s been recommended I do so early. I’m at .06 as of March, just to make it easy, I’m going to cut and paste the post I put up on another forum, with the background, for the guys here that are new enough to not know my backstory....any comments are welcome and appreciated. At the reco of a friend/member here, I met today with the chair of RAd Onc at Cleveland Clinic in Florida. It was a long meeting, and very informative. The short version is.... He recommends treating soon (to review, I was undetectable until the 2 year post op mark, then .02, .033, .033, .046, 060, see signature below) he cited this study... /jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaoncology/article-abstract/2670381?redirect=true A multi institutional study with n=1566, it showed an advantage to treating below .1, vs treating .1 - .5. The entire cohort was adverse pathology. While I had negative final margins, the RO felt that because my frozen section intraoperative margin was positive, and at the apex, my negative final margin was questionable, and he placed a high probability on the PSA coming from cells left in the prostate bed, thus a relatively high probability of a good result. He said if I wanted to wait a few months he didn’t think it would put me at increased risk. He didn’t put too much weight into my low Decipher score, saying I could be one of the 3% that has recurrence, nor did he put much weight in the oncoDx Grid report that predicted poor response to SRT, saying there was not enough data to validate it yet, too small a sample. I also asked him what he thinks might happen if I decided to do nothing. His response, a 50% chance that 10 years from now I would be living a happy life with no issues related to PC. And a 50% chance that I’d have some serious problems in 10 years. I don’t like those odds. He said with their machine, Varian Edge, I think, the chance of permanent side effects was less than 5% (but I should expect transient side effects) I am meeting with Dr Zelefsky, RO at MSKCC, mid June. I will have one more PSA before that meeting. I am inclined to look fir one more increased PSA after the Zelefsky meeting, then taking action, although that also depends on what the pre-Zelefsky PSA shows. I’ve pretty much tossed aside my Surgeons advice to do nothing until/unless i get to .2. I wish their was a black and white answer, but there apparently is not. So the beat goes on. One thing I did not ask, is whether Medicare would approve early Salvage . Anybody know the answer from experience? Good Luck Pratoman! I don't know the answer for medicare, but I'm guessing the answer is probably yes. I'm sure the RO's office will be able to tell you/preapprove. At least it will cost less than for those of us on "regular" insurance (about 10K for my portion). Just as a data point, I have had nothing indicating long-term or permanent side effects (my target was also the prostate bed from positive margins, with similar PSA progression after surgery, albeit faster). I have had a persistent case of radiation proctitis, which has been annoying as hell, but nothing worse. That is finally beginning to subside, I think/hope. I blame my sensitivity on being a (former) redhead! I've got my second post-radiation PSA this week, with hopefully final, followup with RO next week. First post-radiation PSA was down! I think you are correct to consider early intervention...Of course, I did the same thing!

Posts.Title: Validation of ART, I suppose

Posts.Content: Dave, sounds like you've got a good handle on this. I did adjuvant, within the first year, but not very different from your profile. I had a relationship with my RO from initial consultations prior to surgery/decisions. If you've seen one before, that should be an easy no-brainer to get in with him/her. You can probably even get phone referral from docs. Even if you ultimately use a different practitioner. From my discussions with my surgeon and RO, I think some of the "wait longer" thing is related to when you have recurrence. My surgeon was very much in favor of early/aggressive radiation for me. But he noted that if I'd gone longer before indications of adverse stuff, he'd think more about waiting. This was explained as trying to make sure you could target properly. With me, the early PSA rises and adverse pathology pointed strongly to the prostate bed as the likely location to target. He said that if it were couple years from now, they'd wanna wait and make sure there was enough to show up on scans to make sure where/what was happening. RO told similar story. In your case, I think that it sounds like the pathology you had points to the likely disease location -- so you can move ahead with alacrity. I don't think you will have any problem with insurance given the history you've provided. It's not really a question of whether this is a medical necessity, but more of a timing thing. I didn't have any issues in this regard and my RO said that wasn't any problem with insurance when I asked him.... Good Luck!

Posts.Title: One year Result, no man's land follow up.

Posts.Content: Hello and Welcome to the Forum -- there's lots of great folks and helpful information here. I was in your shoes just a few months ago. I'm only 53, so just a bit older. Try and stay calm and absorb things a bit. Your Gleason of 3+3 is about the least aggressive and most easily treated, with the most options, you could have. Gleason 6 doesn't metastasize and often stays indolent for years. Gleason 6 may result in treatment, but is very very unlikely to kill you. Yours has been found early, which is great. My doc also sent my biopsy samples off for genomic testing (well, was supposed to -- mixup meant never happened) The genomic testing will not change your Gleason score. The Gleason is based on the pathologist's assessment of the appearance of the biopsy material. It is possible for different pathologists to assess the slides differently, but there's no reason at this point for you to think this has happened. Your PSA is not very high. The genomic testing is designed to provide additional information to help you refine how you respond. A score will come back that will help your Urologist assess the likelihood that your cancer will become more aggressive or stay pretty indolent. It's kinda sorta like "what's the chance that my Gleason gets worse over time". It's based on genetic markers in the samples and is only to help you and the doc make treatment decisions (very low scores suggest waiting a while is low risk, higher suggest slightly more urgency in deciding on treatment directions. A common genomic test is Oncotype DX, which you can google and read up on -- been used for breast cancer for a while. I think there are others, but reading about Oncotype DX should give you the idea. Once again, sorry you found us by getting a diagnosis, but there's lots of folks here with good experience who'll help and support you throughout. I'd recommend getting the Dr. Patrick Walsh book, Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. lots of wonderful information. I know it sounds crazy, but now's a good time to take a few deep breaths. The numbers you've described are far from an emergency and very curable. Good Luck and ask any questions you have. There's someone here who can provide good answers. Dan

I’ve pretty much tossed aside my Surgeons advice to do nothing until/unless i get to .2. I wish their was a black and white answer, but there apparently is not. So the beat goes on. One thing I did not ask, is whether Medicare would approve early Salvage . Anybody know the answer from experience? Good Luck Pratoman! I don't know the answer for medicare, but I'm guessing the answer is probably yes. I'm sure the RO's office will be able to tell you/preapprove. At least it will cost less than for those of us on "regular" insurance (about 10K for my portion). Just as a data point, I have had nothing indicating long-term or permanent side effects (my target was also the prostate bed from positive margins, with similar PSA progression after surgery, albeit faster). I have had a persistent case of radiation proctitis, which has been annoying as hell, but nothing worse. That is finally beginning to subside, I think/hope. I blame my sensitivity on being a (former) redhead! I've got my second post-radiation PSA this week, with hopefully final, followup with RO next week. First post-radiation PSA was down! I think you are correct to consider early intervention...Of course, I did the same thing!

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Jeff, I'm in a similar boat to RobLee and just finished my course of adjuvant about two weeks ago. I was completely continent when it started and my PSA was not shooting up. In my case, I elected adjuvant without reference to (before they were taken, in fact) post op PSA results. As you do your research, consider the differences in radiation techniques and technology between when your dad likely had it and now. My RO suggested that the overall increase in bladder cancer risk I'd experience from radiation was about 3-5% over 30 years or so. Seemed to me to be lower than chance of a few laggard pCa cells hanging about causing potential trouble. You're just a couple years older than me, so should have a relatively long-term outlook, too, I'd think. I know that the radiation I received was fairly precisely targeted (not to a specific tumor, but area) and they spent a lot of time trying to avoid/minimize bladder and bowel zapping. (In fact, my insurance decided not to cover the imaging they did each day to ensure proper targeting!) Recover a bit and heal a bit and do some research and talk to an RO or two before making up your mind. Pathology, especially negative margins on the removed tissues, seems a positive. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Day 11, post RALP with pathologic data

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your pathology wasn't ideal, Sudds, but sounds like you're still in the cure zone. I'm thinking that Adjuvant Radiation (AR) is what your doc is recommending. This is radiation that is given BEFORE biochemical recurrence. If your PSA post-op comes back very low (like below BR threshold), you will likely not need HT at this time. It's what I'm starting later this month. With the tissues all suffering from the shock of surgery, they hit it with the radiation right away. HT is not generally required with it and the long-term success rates are very good. As a fellow 53 yo (just turned 54), I'm right there in the boat with you, facing a similar situation (my pathology was 4+3 = 7 from 3+3=6 biopsy -- with some Gleason 5 near the positive margin). All of the info I've gotten myself and from my RO suggests this is just another step in the process and not a major speed bump. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: Dave, sounds like you've got a good handle on this. I did adjuvant, within the first year, but not very different from your profile. I had a relationship with my RO from initial consultations prior to surgery/decisions. If you've seen one before, that should be an easy no-brainer to get in with him/her. You can probably even get phone referral from docs. Even if you ultimately use a different practitioner. From my discussions with my surgeon and RO, I think some of the "wait longer" thing is related to when you have recurrence. My surgeon was very much in favor of early/aggressive radiation for me. But he noted that if I'd gone longer before indications of adverse stuff, he'd think more about waiting. This was explained as trying to make sure you could target properly. With me, the early PSA rises and adverse pathology pointed strongly to the prostate bed as the likely location to target. He said that if it were couple years from now, they'd wanna wait and make sure there was enough to show up on scans to make sure where/what was happening. RO told similar story. In your case, I think that it sounds like the pathology you had points to the likely disease location -- so you can move ahead with alacrity. I don't think you will have any problem with insurance given the history you've provided. It's not really a question of whether this is a medical necessity, but more of a timing thing. I didn't have any issues in this regard and my RO said that wasn't any problem with insurance when I asked him.... Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: Hello and Welcome to the Forum -- there's lots of great folks and helpful information here. I was in your shoes just a few months ago. I'm only 53, so just a bit older. Try and stay calm and absorb things a bit. Your Gleason of 3+3 is about the least aggressive and most easily treated, with the most options, you could have. Gleason 6 doesn't metastasize and often stays indolent for years. Gleason 6 may result in treatment, but is very very unlikely to kill you. Yours has been found early, which is great. My doc also sent my biopsy samples off for genomic testing (well, was supposed to -- mixup meant never happened) The genomic testing will not change your Gleason score. The Gleason is based on the pathologist's assessment of the appearance of the biopsy material. It is possible for different pathologists to assess the slides differently, but there's no reason at this point for you to think this has happened. Your PSA is not very high. The genomic testing is designed to provide additional information to help you refine how you respond. A score will come back that will help your Urologist assess the likelihood that your cancer will become more aggressive or stay pretty indolent. It's kinda sorta like "what's the chance that my Gleason gets worse over time". It's based on genetic markers in the samples and is only to help you and the doc make treatment decisions (very low scores suggest waiting a while is low risk, higher suggest slightly more urgency in deciding on treatment directions. A common genomic test is Oncotype DX, which you can google and read up on -- been used for breast cancer for a while. I think there are others, but reading about Oncotype DX should give you the idea. Once again, sorry you found us by getting a diagnosis, but there's lots of folks here with good experience who'll help and support you throughout. I'd recommend getting the Dr. Patrick Walsh book, Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. lots of wonderful information. I know it sounds crazy, but now's a good time to take a few deep breaths. The numbers you've described are far from an emergency and very curable. Good Luck and ask any questions you have. There's someone here who can provide good answers. Dan

Posts.Title: 48 y/o Newbie

Posts.Content: I think you're getting lots of good advice. I understand the waiting is hard -- I, too, was tempted to invent things to worry about. From what you've indicated, your docs haven't suggested there's an expectation it's left the organ. So, it's best to assume it has not. That means positive margins are not expected, either. If you have any sort of upgrade on pathology post surgery, deal with that then. Every case is different and specific, so what margins mean and such is also specific to an individual case. As Dave pointed out, positive margins, when they occur, don't always mean any changes for you anyway. You'll have seen reports of 30% of pathology is upgraded post surgery. Don't forget, that means that 70% of the time it isn't. Bet on the 70% and clean margins.

Posts.Title: Accuracy of online Calculators

Posts.Content: I'm sure that others with more experience will chime in, but here's my two cents worth. I've looked into the same questions, just as many of us have. Hopefully, with your solid surgery and pathology results this never troubles you again! Most surgery folks gleefully watch their PSA settle at zero/undetectable after surgery. Then they monitor PSA levels to catch biochemical recurrence (BR) if it happens, showing something is happening again. At this point, they typically receive salvage radiation. This is often/usually accompanied by some level of HT, often six months prior to and 24 months post-radiation. The HT is to weaken the cancer cells to improve radiation efficacy. At least, this is what my RO tells me. Normally, BR, if it occurs, is more than two years, frequently more than five years down the road from RP surgery. Generally, BR within two years is indicative of more aggressive cancer and can result in more aggressive HT/treatment. Some folks, like myself, have post-surgical findings that suggest a more aggressive approach may be appropriate. Things like significant positive margins (especially with higher grade pathology), seminal vesicle involvement, etc. In this case, adjuvant radiation may be suggested. Adjuvant and Salvage radiation are essentially the same thing, just with different timing. Adjuvant is a course of radiation that commences, usually within a year of RP, while the tissues should be already weakened by the removal of the prostate/surgery. In this case, HT is usually not indicated (presuming PSA is undetectable after RP). If PSA does not fall to undetectable levels, or more extensive cancer is indicated, HT can be the same -- which makes it identical to salvage. Adjuvant has been shown to reduce BR, or maybe better stated, push BR into the future more. In both cases, if you have a BR after the radiation, your treatment options shift. ASAdvocate has recently provided links to studies indicating that SBRT (higher dose focused radiation in 1-5 treatments) may be effective as followup (especially where defined tumor sites can be identified, I believe). Otherwise, my understanding is that a general progression is HT as long as it is effective, followed by combinations of chemotherapy/radiotherapy depending on the cancer's location and dimensions. In any case, for most of us, the third round of treatments will not be in the picture. Keep in mind, that for most of us with Gleason grade 6/7 findings, there is a significant time lapse between surgery, possible BR, and then, IF it occurs, second BR -- on the order of ten to twenty years. For the average patient, diagnosed at 67 or so, that would mean being in your eighties or more before having to progress to the chemo-based treatments. Even then, many years of high-quality life are in store. In your case, with confined grade 6 and successful surgery, you have a very low probability of ever getting to BR, or even more remotely, a second recurrence. I hope this helps and that it's not inaccurate (I'm sure others will correct me if I've mis-spoken or erred).

Posts.Content: Of course I have no idea what to advise for you, but I can offer my results. I had what was expected to be low-risk cancer that had not escaped. My doc planned to and actually did spare both nerve bundles. Although I did have a positive margin that's gonna result in additional treatments, it wasn't part of the nerve bundles and the pathology on seminal vessicles , lymph nodes, and other tissues were all clear. My margin was along the urethra at the apex. For what it's worth. I was essentially continent on day one post-catheter and there are signs of erectile function returning (don't know what I'll get before radiation next month) beginning at four months. I think it's possible to have nerve sparing and good results...

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: FWIW, all of my practitioners, including the surgical URO and RO, tell me that the "fixing" of both continence and ED is essentially permanent. I got shown a lot of charts and such that basically said, once the RT starts, you will suffer a slight regression in both capabilities, which will bounce back some. However, after the bounce back (which takes a while), you will still be no higher/better than you were on day one of RT. That is the primary reason for the healing delay between RP and RT. In my case, I pushed the AR back an extra month (so I could finish Dec 29th, the last billing day of the year for my insurance) just to try and get a little better ED response. The RO didn't think it would really matter, but did it 'cause it wouldn't hurt, either. So far, the RO has been right -- but don't tell him, I'm still hoping.... In my case, I've been 100% continent (basically don't even think about it almost all of the time, just have to pucker up when making odd lifts suddenly and getting an almost surprise) for a couple of months -- that was the big hurdle they were tracking. So my RO says after everything, I should end up either 100% continent or virtually so, but may spend some time in pads in the interim.... Hope this helps answer the question. I'll be able to provide first hand evidence/testimony sometime after Nov 1st -- although supposedly doesn't set in immediately. Good Luck!
