Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: As suggested, MrBaseball, now's the time to do the crash education effort. I'm a little older than you, but still on the younger end of the PCa spectrum. I know when I went to the doctor and had the biopsy and got the results, I was not really expecting to hear cancer. It takes a little time to adjust. I also generally prefer doing something, so I dove into reading the Dr. Patrick Walsh book, this and other online sources, and such to learn about the disease and a lot of the things I was hearing from my Uro and other practitioners. As mentioned above, it would seem likely that given your age, you'll hear recommendations for surgery. My age was a significant factor in me choosing surgery, too. As we'll all say, we are not medical professionals, but I think the partin information is providing some statistics from the "Partin Tables", which are statistical nomograms developed by (I believe) the folks at Johns Hopkins. These are basically developed by tracking a large number of patients, inputting biopsy information, age, etc., and clinical outcomes. You can then enter the known facts about your case and out pops the statistical probability of certain outcomes/findings based on the large number of patients they've tracked. It is not tuned to you personally in any way other than using your biopsy data and age, etc. In your case, it seems to indicate that based on the biopsy details and your age, the tables indicate a 25% chance its fully contained within the prostate, 44% chance that it is involved in the extraprostatic tissue (immediate prostate surroundings, like fatty tissue), and just 17% and 14% respectively for seminal vesicles and lymph nodes, respectively. The numbers in parentheses look like the actual percentage ranges. But this is a good question to ask your doc. Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Recurrence - PSA rising after Prostate Surgery - next steps?

Posts.Content: Hey Mike, congrats on getting through the surgery and immediate post-op period successfully. I'll second RobLee about the good chances you will have adjuvant radiation at least suggested. It will depend on exactly how they interpret the details of your post-pathology, but as Rob notes, the SVI/T3 staging is one of the indicators for adjuvant followup. The six month window is about right for that discussion. In my case (positive margin made treatment planning as if stage 3), we had the first conversations and initial scheduling about a month after surgery. All of this without reference to a PSA, which wasn't taken until 3 months out. My radiation began in Oct, about six months after April surgery. I waited until I had really good continence. The followup PSA results were used to determine that I did not need HT at this time (because it was low). You are unlikely to get a recommendation for any RT before you've done some healing and gotten your continence back. So take the next six months and just get healed. Good Luck from a fellow Texan -- you'll be going back just after the folk festival, so enjoy it!

Posts.Content: Yeah, Southsider, I don't know what happened. I know he usually does his RP surgeries Tue/Wed/Thu, two or three each day. I don't know what he does on the other days. His office indicated that he was "held up", so I'm guessing something took longer or started later than planned. He's the director of robotic surgery for the hospital and their multiple DaVinci machines, so could have been someone else's problem, too, I suppose. He was rescheduling his "entire afternoon schedule" and I was the last thing on the day (his consult appointment right as they're closing up...it's the same slot he uses to give biopsy results -- waiting room is empty and most of the support staff gone by then. Once I explained, they consulted his nurse and rescheduled for Friday (then called back next day and moved that one earlier in the day).

Posts.Title: Finally have first Post-OP PSA

Posts.Content: My Uro Surgeon is Dr. Peter Ruff, with Urology Austin. I can highly recommend. He works with a couple hospitals, but is director of robotic surgery at St. David's. I used the South Austin location of St. Davids, which is across the street from his office. Probably won't get another PSA until after the radiation, unless they tell me differently. I had hoped for undetectable, but am not totally shocked. The margin, with grade 4 and 5 near the margin, kinda prepared me for possibility of not perfect results. I think the reason the doc waited this long to take first PSA was to get a "good" read after completely settling from surgery. If I'd have gotten this number or higher a couple months ago, all I would have done is worry until a second one was taken now. I'll have to wait until I see Dr. Ruff on Friday and the RO on Monday to see how concerned they are. I'm really just hoping to avoid the HT as that seems to be the most undesireable side effect profile among the brothers here....

Posts.Content: My Uro Surgeon is Dr. Peter Ruff, with Urology Austin. I can highly recommend. He works with a couple hospitals, but is director of robotic surgery at St. David's. I used the South Austin location of St. Davids, which is across the street from his office. Probably won't get another PSA until after the radiation, unless they tell me differently. I had hoped for undetectable, but am not totally shocked. The margin, with grade 4 and 5 near the margin, kinda prepared me for possibility of not perfect results. I think the reason the doc waited this long to take first PSA was to get a "good" read after completely settling from surgery. If I'd have gotten this number or higher a couple months ago, all I would have done is worry until a second one was taken now. I'll have to wait until I see Dr. Ruff on Friday and the RO on Monday to see how concerned they are. I'm really just hoping to avoid the HT as that seems to be the most undesireable side effect profile among the brothers here....
